												For those that missed the first episode of Sonic 4, this is a 2D platforming game staring everyone's favorite blue hedgehog. The plot is the same as its always been, but with a twist. Dr. Robotnik, the evil antagonist of most every Sonic game has now teamed up with Metal Sonic! The dude with 90s attitude isn't alone though, he now has Tails to go with him. With Tails, come new mechanics, such as jumping into the air, and calling Tails to lift Sonic like a helicopter. If you're on the ground and use the tag button, it summons Tails to combine the two for a super fast attack. If you need to use the helicopter ability, the game will have a little billboard to tell you. This game feels more a kin to the Game Boy Advance games than the original Genesis games which the first episode clearly drew inspiration from.In Episode 2, you have four zones with three acts each followed by a boss fight as a fourth act. Not just that, but later into the four hour game, you unlock a playable Metal Sonic with four zones and one act each. These zones use assets from the first episode. So in all, there are 16+ levels for you to master. These levels feel a lot longer than the first episode and the Genesis games as a whole. Some levels feel like six minute marathons with no end in sight.The levels are big and offer many paths to the exit. You'll have to avoid an array of enemies, spikes, and even death traps. You'll collect rings everywhere and these rings aren't just because dullards love shinny things, but as long as Sonic has at least one ring, he can take another hit. Even if you have 100 rings and get hit, only 30 will spray out of Sonic. When you get hit with no rings, it means death for the fuzzy blue guy. There are plenty of check points in each level if you die. A game over simply means that you'll need to start the level again. If you collect 100 rings in a level, you get an extra life. If you have 50+ rings at the end of the level, a giant ring will appear that will take you to a special bonus stage.These bonus stages are updated versions of the old Sonic 2 bonus stages. You'll follow Sonic running down a 3D half pipe. You can boost and jump. There are a few check points that need X amount of rings to get past. So as Sonic, you'll solemn down the tube moving left and right, collecting rings and dodging obstacles that will lose you rings. At the end you'll find a chaos emerald.... that somehow isn't green. Whatever. Collect all seven to unlock a yellow Super Sonic.New to the Sonic 4 series is local co-op and even online co-op, but since the game came out in 2011, good luck trying to find a partner. There are online leader boards for time attacks. It adds to the replayability I guess, but more than that, the game has a red star ring on each level to collect. These rings are either tough to find or tough to get. Its an extra challenge for veterans.Sonic and Metal Sonic play the same. Left and right to move, with a single button to jump. Hold down to duck and hit the jump button to start a spin dash to get momentum to go up slopes. You still need to charge it which takes time. That's why the airborne dart attack is not only a much better way to gain speed instantly, but you can also lock in on targets accurately hit them no matter what the angle. Episode 2 didn't make as much use of the homing attack as the first episode, but it does make travel easier, darting for an enemy or a springboard. The only difference between Metal Sonic and the ordinary version is lack of an ally. No helicoptering around or bowling through enemies.Calling Tails just feels slow. Tails automatically zips right back to Sonic wherever he is, unless he just died, but it just halts the game to wait. The Sky Fortress kicks off with an airplane mission that has Sonic atop Tail's plane that gives you full control to move the plane left, right, up and down. Complete with Sonic able to jump and attack. Under normal circumstances, I'd think it diversifies gameplay having a plane dodge enemies and twirl through barricades to destroy them. This felt like a slow auto scrolling level (act). There was still a part where the 2D platforming returned, but then it was just back to being on top of a plane. It felt dull, slow and boring. Then having to fight the boss on the plane was unfun.The real snag that I have for this game is how long and dull the boss battles are. They take traditional, classic boss battles and completely twist them around into mega bosses. See I like the twists and fighting giant bosses, I just don't like how tedious every boss was. Having to damage each boss for three minutes before the final phase of the boss fight left me clueless and dead ate up most of my 4 hours in the game. These 3 minutes on each attempt felt like 10 and I was never in any real danger. It wasn't a challenge surviving the 3 minutes, it was just a delay for the real challenge. At least the game takes full advantage of having Metal Sonic as an enemy. You get three boss fights against him.The game has other down sides too, like a timed race against sand flooding an area. Sonic needs to go up, breaking through barriers, then down. This would separate the casual players from the hardcore. It ate up two dozen lives and was quite the difficulty spike. Then on the final two levels, when Sonic went down hill or uphill, the entire screen would shift so Sonic wasn't running downhill, he was on a horizontal plane. It was disorienting, and might cause someone motion sickness.Water areas feel better in this game than they have in the past. Sonic jumps higher and Tails can carry him, so you have more maneuverability. Under water still slows down Sonic and he can't swim. If you're underwater too long, Sonic will need to get oxygen from big air bubbles that drift their way up.The soundtrack feels Genesis in a good way. Percussion and synth horns. Its all upbeat happy game music. The graphics are bright and vibrant. There is a good color pallet here. A dusty yellow castle with an aquatic greenish blue moat. A winter wonderland theme park, lit up for a holiday with blue ice water. A metallic sandy red oil rig in a yellow desert. A yellow sky fortress with fans to propel Sonic into the air. Dr. Robotnik's gray and purple metal lair. As each zone progressed, the acts would change their color pallets so you'll see day turn to dusk. It all adds to making each of the three acts feel different. Having Metal Sonic's 4 different zones with 1 act each adds a lot of diversity, even if 3 acts each would have been nicer.Even with all the bad, its still a good game. Better than most other 2D platforms out there for $15. I enjoyed the first episode better, but it felt like they took the gameplay a step in the right direction. If its on sale, take a risk.

												While not as shockingly bad as Episode 1, Sonic 4 Ep. 2 really doesn't improve upon the formula all that much. It's a tired retread that doesn't come close to any of the Genesis games. There are positive qualities: The storyline is non-existent, a Hedgehog isn't revived by a kiss, the music is bland but okay, and um...yeah that's about it. More than anything else, I appreciate Sonic 4 simply because it makes the previous games look so much better by comparison. Once again, the first major failing of Episode 2 is the level-design. Everything feels cramped. It's a combination of the camera being zoomed-in too much, a lack of anything note-worthy nearby, and a general absence of "flow". All of the stages have this boxy feel to them. It's like they were slapped together by some sort of map-maker and the results are really unnatural. Good levels are supposed to be sketched out before-hand, like a storyboard. It allows for the designer to develop a specific theme. In this game, it's more along the lines of: we'll have some jumps, then a ramp, and here's a loop, oh and another loop sounds good, then we'll follow up with some rings, and then... The levels are stretched out enough to fill some allotted amount of time (2-4 minutes), and that's it.Every zone in the 2D Sonic games has a different tile-set. Imagine if for Sonic 1, every zone looked like Green Hill. Spring Yard would look like Green Hill. Labyrinth? Green Hill. Starlight? Take a wild guess. Even though every zone looked like one another, they would still be very different, because they have concepts and themes unique to each of them. Every zone in Sonic 4 Ep. 2 is visually distinct, and yet they all feel so similar to each other it doesn't matter. There is the standard array of springs, ramps, traps, and enemy robots. Nothing really changes beyond "Hey you gotta go fast here".When Episode 2 tries new ideas, the results are middling at best. Tails is along for this trek, and the BFFs can perform team-up actions. At practically any moment you can get an assist from Tails to reach higher areas, create a super rolling attack, or swim. The system is implemented awkwardly, as most of the flying sections are forced. Also, due to the poor level-design, it never feels like you've discovered a shortcut or a secret when flying around. This I attribute to the claustrophobic aspects of the level-design. Since you can never see too far in front of you, nothing looks out of reach. Part of the appeal of finding secrets like 1ups and red rings is that you can see them, but you have to consider how they can be collected. In this game, if there's something you can't get to, it's probably because you took a different route. I guess this is to encourage replay value, but it's at the cost of exploration, which isn't a good trade-off.Another issue with Tails and - by extension the level-design - is the mechanics. When flying, you have to be careful when approaching cliffs from below. If you press against the wall, what will happen is that Tails will step onto the cliff, and Sonic will fall to his death. This doesn't crop up very often, except for the sections where you're forced to rely on Tails to fly. As with Sonic 4 Ep. 1, the hardest part of any act is towards the end. To put it another way, these parts are the only time where death is a real possibility. They can involve a lot of traps, stupid pet tricks, or other gimmicks. The unbalanced difficulty makes the rest of the act feel like padding. Sonic The Hedgehog games tend to be easy, but there is still some sort of balance, with the later zones being more challenging than the early zones. With this game, all of the difficulty is in these end-of-act sections. The boss-fights are garbage. Metal Sonic makes his less-than-triumphant return for this adventure. I've always liked its design, and the Sonic CD "boss-fight" was really cool. In this game, he's ran into the ground. Every other boss-fight involves a duel with Metal Sonic, and the encounters all have this samey design to them. You're constantly running, trying to get a hit on the hedgebot, but an invisible force pushes you backwards while he performs various attacks. You'll fight Robotnik (or was it Eggman?) a few times as well. These fights just run way too long. Some of them start with an interesting look or a cool visual, but then they drag on and on for several minutes. I especially dislike the third boss. It's far too easy, but then in order to get the last hit, you have to awkwardly lure him to the right spot, just to land a super rolling attack.As a "bonus", if you own both this game and Episode 1, you get to play a shortened version of Episode 1 starring Metal Sonic. Apparently it takes place shortly after Sonic CD, but I don't care about that. It adds an unnecessary convoluted twist to a storyline that didn't need it. All that really needs to be said is that Robotnik is back, and so is Metal Sonic. It's a freaking robot! Eggman probably just rebuilt the son of a ♥♥♥♥♥, or made a new one. Your best bet is ignoring Sonic Team's attempt at tricking unsuspecting gamers into playing through Episode 1 again. Yes it's a shorter and re-arranged version of the game, but the level-design is still absolutely wretched.Jon Rooke, the European Marketing Director at SEGA, recently had this to say: “Sega has publicly apologised to the fans as the quality of console games in the Sonic franchise hasn’t been acceptable over recent years. It’s been tough translating that iconic side scrolling 2D experience from the 90s into 3D but Sonic is still huge for us so the new games will be more inspired by how it played in its heyday." It's a nice gesture. However, I can't shake the feeling that we'll end up with Sonic 5. I'm certain that it'll star Knuckles, every zone will be a half-hearted throwback to Sonic 3, and it's going to be a thoroughly miserable experience.

												After being disappointed with Sonic 4 Episode I, a return to Sonic's 2D roots that featured some ugly art design and a brutal phsyics engine, I wasn't expecting much from Episode II. Surprisingly though, I ended up having quite a bit of fun with the sequel. The physics engine is upgraded considerably and, while still not perfect, now feels much closer to the Genesis-era games. The hideous cel-shaded character design from the first episode was also ditched in favor of a cleaner look. Level design and boss battles are also improved from Episode I. The newly-introduced "Tag Actions" feel fresh and make for some nice platforming sequences as well. On the downside, the soundtrack is hit-or-miss (mostly miss) and a little more zone variety would've been nice.While still not on the level of the the 2D Sonic games from the Genesis days, Sonic 4 Episode II manages to hold its own and provide an enjoyable experience that retains that classic Sonic feel while tossing in a few fresh twists here and there. Worth playing if you're a fan of the series.

When I read that Metal Sonic returns and Little Planet from Sonic CD is back, on top of Tails being here, I got irritated. "Oh boy, Sonic 2 + Sonic CD!" 												Sonic 4 - Episode II actually does a lot to improve on its predecesor, though it's still somewhat flawed. This time, the physics are a bit better, as Sonic does have inertia, but they still don't feel like the originals, especially when Sonic is curled up into a ball. When you're curled into a ball, you go slower but are less vulnerable to enemies while freely running lets you move faster at the cost of being easier to hit. It doesn't feel like the original Sonic games but it does stand up fairly well on its own. Tails is also here, giving you an arsenal of team-attacks you can do, which does add some depth to the game, albeit breaking the pace up at times. The stages are more creative this time around as well, as they are totally rendered in 3D and combine stage ideas from previous games. The music still has the weird instrumentation from the first one, however, and towards the end of the game they start getting more lazy with reusing tracks. That said, it feels like a much more competent Sonic game than the first episode and I'd like to see a conclusion, but that's probably not happening.

												Sonic the Hedgehog, that little blue ball of fur. He whizzes around in a blur. Faster than a speeding bullet. The thrill! The exhilaration! Those wonderful feelings that come to mind whenever I think of Sonic and his buddies. When thinking of a character like Sonic, it's hard to separate nostalgia from true feelings. Hopefully I'll be able to do that!Sonic 4: E2 is a fun platformer. Colourful landscapes, and cute enemies create a vibrant atmosphere. The graphics are acceptable for a 2D game in this generation. The game struggles to run on low end machines, even those that pass the system requirements. The game just isn't playable with system lag, or low FPS.The gameplay is okay, but I do have a few issues. To me Sonic was a different kind of platformer. It was all about whizzing through the levels as fast as possible. I got great joy from timing my jumps just right, getting enough coins for the special levels and bouncing off the enemies on the way. Unfortunately S4E2 doesn't feel right. Sonic at full speed feels sluggish, and that's a word you never want associated with our heroic hedgehog. I never felt out of control, Sonic never flew off the screen. Some people might call that a good thing, but I think a fair few fans would agree with my perspective.I was able to play some levels co-op. The levels are the same, one player controls Sonic, the other Tails. The problem with co-op is as soon as one character gets a little bit away from the other, the player behind has to use the catch up button. This just made the game feel like a chaotic mess. However, this chaotic mess was extremely fun. It enabled some awesome near-death escapes.The game is trying hard to be like the 2D Sonic games of old. It introduces some new abilities, like forming a super-ball of death with Tails (which is the best way to go through 80% of levels), or dashing through the air by double jumping. Ultimately this is where it fails. It's an okay platformer, and it has a pricepoint that reflects the length of the game but it doesn't stand up to classic Sonic games.Whilst the game does not stand up against previous Sonic games, it is quite a fun platformer. The levels are a nice length and fun to run through once. There isn't much replayability there though.Bottom Line: Fun co-op game. A little lacklustre when compared to classic Sonic.

												Sonic 4 Episode 2 is a game I'm completely inconsistent with. I played it for half an hour and thought it wasn't worth playing through, played it again from beginning to end and hated it, and then played it through again and honestly thought it was on par with the Genesis games.In comparison to Episode 1 it's definitely better. The physics are improved and the graphics no longer look like New Super Mario Bros. but worse. A lot of people complained that classic Sonic was absent from the first game, and took it way overboard, but I kinda do agree that modern looks really unnatural here. Thankfully there's a mod for that anyway if it bothers you that much.The game controls a lot better than Ep1 and it's at least satisfying in this game, but still not quite as solid as in the classic games or even Generations. Sonic feels like he lacks weight on the ground and momentum building isn't quite right, sometimes requiring homing attack spamming just to reach your max speed on the ground.The level themes are all blatantly reused concepts with the exception of White Park which while I can compare it to some levels it doesn't outright copy anything. I hate the fact that a game selling itself as Sonic 4 is almost nothing but recycled levels and enemies, but the levels themselves have so many new concepts that it's still pretty fresh as a whole, and the likenesses of Episode 2's levels to classic levels isn't as offensive as in Ep1... with the exception of Sky Fortress which is nearly identical.The game's visuals are absolutely gorgeous. I'd say Sonic 4 Ep2 is the most scenic game in the series. It's incredibly polished visually. I can't say the same about the soundtrack, though. While I initially really hated it, I realized on subsequent playthroughs with Super Sonic available I never used him for just one reason; I didn't want to stop the level music. While I do actually really love the compositions themselves, the instrumentation is horrid. They clearly went for a Genesis style tinny-ness to the synths but it just sounds awful on some tracks, specifically Sky Fortress Act II and the Death Egg's theme, two songs which I would actually really like if they used better synths.Oh yeah it's also really short. This game has five zones in total and 25 levels in all if you count the boss levels and special stages. I think with a casual runthrough of both this and Sonic 2, Sonic 2 would still be longer, but I consider Sonic 2 to be fairly short for a Sonic game I dunno. Completing the game without all of the Chaos Emeralds yields a message to go collect them, but there's really no reason to, because it does nothing to the ending. Little Planet is still stuck inside the Death Egg while Sonic and Tails feel good about themselves in their escape pods. This could be thought of as a lead-in to Episode 3, but as of now Sega has no plans for one. One of the developers has said that they might make one if Ep2 sold well. Did it? I dunno but I certainly don't want the Sonic 4 series to end like this.The game was actually short enough that I turned to achievement hunting to elongate it. Which was odd as this was after I'd already had my fill of this game and dismissed it as another bad Sonic entry. I actually WANTED to come back to collect achievements and actually found a lot of fun with the game, both in gathering the achievements and just playing the game itself. However I will say that the achievements are absolutely pointless. Certain gameplay elements like the Red Rings and presence and abundance of rings before boss encounters were clearly just implemented for the game's achievements on release, but getting said achievements has no bearing on the actual game whatsoever. Collecting all the Red Rings or getting the last hit on every boss as Super Sonic, none of this affects the game at all. It doesn't even have a list of the achievements in game so really it's questionable why they're even there other than to make this short game slightly longer.All in all though I did find a lot of fun with this. The game's length as well as reused settings are the biggest problems, but they're pretty well made up for with a beautiful presentation, pretty enjoyable music and most of all a lot of good level gimmicks and physical designs. Is it as good as the classics? Eh, probably not, if only because it's not completely orginal, but I had just about as much fun with it anyway.

												Like all games, StH4 has its problems, but I don't think that ruins it for the game. While it's very true that you're going to have far easier a time with a controller than a keyboard/mouse, overall, the game is very well put together. Piece by piece, here's what I think.The music, like for all Sonic games, is very well done and feels very fitting. Every single stage sounds appropriate, from White Park Zone sounding very much like a snowy wonderland to Oil Desert Zone sounding like an intimidating desert factory. The music itself is composed fantastically, with nothing in it that would grate on the ears, and even the new power-up music doesn't sound too bad.The controls and physics take some getting used to, especially if you haven't played a game with Sonic's acceleration need; thankfully, it's been improved somewhat from Episode 1, making it less bothersome. They can also be frustrating at times, but once you get over the slight learning curve, it never feels rage-inducing or overly frustrating. Annoying at times, yes, but at least here, it won't ever feel like the game is actively hating you and all you stand for. Sky Fortress' changed controls can take a bit to adapt to, especially if you're playing co-op, but other than that, failures mostly feel like skill or mistakes rather than bad controls.The Zone desgins are wonderful as well. Each Zone gives a feel of some of the older games' Zones, but at the same time, they also have unique little twists or tricks that makes them feel like their own unique places as well. From White Park's snowy theme park feeling to Oil Desert's very industrialized setting, even if there aren't as many of them as in other games, they leave a mark.The game is, despite some claims, not that much shorter than the other four games it emulates (Sonic 1, 2, 3, S&K). While there are only 4 normal Zones, every Zone has 3 Acts, plus a stand-alone "act" that's the boss of that Zone (not counting the final Zone). As an added bonus, you can replay any Special Zone you've beaten for fun, or to practice for harder ones.Speaking of the Special Zone, the special stages from Sonic 2 make a return! And to add to the fun of the "friendly competition" of the ring gathering, the animation played when going between checkpoints is actually different depending on which character has the most rings. The stages, as usual, can be easy or hard depending on how good you are at picking up rings while dodging, but they definitely have the same feel as the old-school ones.The co-op for the game can be either a blessing or a curse, depending on if you have someone to play with or not. The game feels very much like it was built specifically FOR two players to work together on it, which means if you do have two people, you can do a lot you wouldn't get to do or pull off some neat tricks. At the same time, if you're playing alone, it can sometimes be a little frustrating or difficult precisely because of the build intending two people.All in all, it's definitely not a perfect game by any means... but it's a game that those who enjoy that style of gameplay should, in my opinion, pick up if they can, regardless of whether they're a Sonic fan or not. Those who are fans of the old-style Sonic, however, will definitely find even more enjoyment in it with all the throwbacks. However, I would DEFINITELY reccomend a controller if at all possible.SEGA managed to make something that felt both old-school and unique with Sonic 4 Episode 2... and how many games can claim that?

Please note:This review is based on my own experiences with this product; Yours could be different. This game is part of a franchise, so it will probably be compared to other games of such.This genre is unlikely to have the following, so these might be only spoken about: StoryRate responsibly.Gameplay - 8.5/10The Main Menu is now bigger, offers a Leaderboard, Multiplayer option (Local and surprisingly, Online) and the settings customization, both outside the game and inside the game feels much better. You get an Special Metal Sonic episode for completing Episode 1 (YES! I guess all the suffering got me something!), which you play Metal Sonic after the happenings of Sonic CD up to the first time you meet him at this episode, at the Sonic gameplay. The default key bindings for Keyboards have been totally changed, as the game also requires the player to use more buttons due to combo actions. The game doesn't really start off from where Episode 1 ended and neither introduces us to an story, but now features Tails as the rocket at the ending supposed. I had a hard time trying to play with the Keyboard, so i changed to the Steam Controller and i had no issues anymore. You can't select other zones that not Sylvania Castle while you don’t get through ACT 3. I got surprised when i thought for a second that the boss that appears at the starts of Sylvania Castle Zone ACT 3 would be just a recreation of the Sonic 2 totem one, but then, it happens! Speaking of that, all the boss battles on Episode 2 are brand new and it is great to once again have bigger threats through acts and not only on boss acts, even when those are just weaker versions from the final boss of the zone. At least, it is still something newly created.The level design feels way better than the ones at Episode 1. The use of Tails help is a great gameplay mechanic that changes from Flying (which can also be used to get better mobility inside the water) and Combo spinning, moves that gets the boss fights to be exciting and a test that you know how to make great use of those skills. The gameplay of Special Stages is great, just the same from Sonic 2, my favorite being followed by the one featured on Sonic 1. Normal acts aren't hard, but require the player to understand and master each's mechanic. The return of sky aboard (Tornado/Tail's Airplane) act is amazing and challenging, just as the Boss Act of Sky Fortress. The correct use of combo skills at the last boss gets it to be way less challenging than it should, but you're still likely to die and if you do, it is all the way back, and it is a considerably long boss. I didn't try out the multiplayer mode, but other reviews confirm both local and online works properly. The Metal episode is challenging and features camping enemies (Do you remember the crabs and crickets on Sonic 2 that wouldn't let you go up and used to get your rings to 0, and then kill you? Yea, those.) The levels on the Metal Episode are pretty much about the same from Episode 1, but with some alternate routes and minor level design changes to get you to the points that draw the Metal Sonic story the episode is supposed to. It is not a huge thing, but at least it is a gameplay bonus and a reward from playing Episode 1 (Because we REALLY deserved one after that.). I still miss being able to play the game as other character, though.Story - 8/10Sonic 4: Episode 2 doesn’t start with an introduction to an story, but draws one and quite explains what was up at Episode 1 as the game goes. Eggman, after beaten in his previous installment on Little Planet (the main setting of Sonic CD), started planning his entire intentions from the very beginning of Episode 1, when the satellite would start to approach once more and be an opportunity for the villain. As Sonic and Tails face and battle Eggman and Metal Sonic through the game, some details such as what the villain was searching for in the Lost Labyrinth and what Mad Gear was built for start to unfold, leading to the final boss at Little Planet.Episode's Metal plot, besides short and not really important, happens and starts at the same spot Episode 2 does, properly explains how Metal Sonic acquired even more power and why he first appears on the Snow Park zone riding Tails' Rocket.Graphics/Art - 9.5/10Finally, not only the UI/HUD won't look blurry as they did at Episode 1, by the fact Episode 2 properly offers resolutions higher than 720p, but the models and textures are going to be displayed properly. Everything looks so great that it is almost impossible to believe the game was built by the same team that worked on Episode 1. The 3D models look way better, the animations are well worked, the lightning fits and the background truly attracts the player attention; Everything is breathtaking. Such amazing look and the fact it was released after 2 years, almost for the exact same platforms Episode 1 was is a proof that Episode 1 could've done way better. For a moment, I thought the heavy work on graphics could lead to a poor gameplay, but it didn't. The Snow Park zone doesn't only looks amazing, as also plays cool. Each zone is charming at its own way and features proper enemies. There is a mod available for those who aren't comfortable with the modern Sonic & Tails model that replaces it with the classic Sonic & Tails model from Sonic Generations and works just fines with minor animations issues and no game crashes. Even the signs at the end of each act are properly changed.Talking about the Metal Episode, besides the fact the levels are pretty much about the same from Episode 1, it is worth being able to now see the past landscapes at proper resolution. Soundtrack - 8.5/10It is also possible to detect improvements on the soundtrack. Besides Episode's 1 soundtrack was fair, the one in Episode 2 fits even more to each zone and act, easily catching the player's attention (Or at least my attention). The Sky Fortress zone, for example, features songs that both fits with its act and the other acts of the zone, what clearly creates the sense it fits with the zone itself. General - 8.5/10My expectations were high on this one, and I’m happy they were. Sonic 4: Episode 2 delivers a much better experience to the player than Episode 1 did. The Super combo attack and the combo moves adds a special charm to the use of both characters, followed by a special taste to the gameplay. The game received a low metascore that, at least on my opinion, it didn't really deserve. Besides it was never said Episode 1 received a low budget, the Sega Brand Manager Ken Balough mentioned Episode 2 would have a larger budget than Episode I, due to the latter being received very well commercially (I'm really glad he only said commercially). Sonic 4: Episode 2 is, at least, everything that Episode 1 didn't delivered us. It is almost impossible to think that Episode 2 was produced by the same team of Episode 1, and it gets me to want to forget the latter exists.TL;DRSONIC THE HEDGEHOG 4 Episode II feels ridiculously better than Episode I. In addition to the amazing graphic, the game offers a lot of new customizations and configurations at the same time new gameplay features are introduced to the player, challenged to use each new feature at the right situation on its favor.

There's also no copying of any of the previous zones from old Sonic games, but some zones are similar to other zones seen in the Sonic series, but I can't really list them all.The story is really hard to notice due to all of the characters refusing to talk during the entire game, in all seriousness a storyline isn't really here in this game.This game relies way too heavily on the special Sonic + Tails moves, most of the game requires you to use those moves. Like in Oil Desert Zone act 2 or 3, the end of the act requires you to use the flying-Tails-carrying-Sonic thing for the rest of the act, and I've died a few times in that part.The Co-op mode is ok, and suprisingly it is accurate to Sonic 2's co-op mode: You both have to stay on the same gosh darn screen.It's still not a worthy sequel to the Sega Genesis Sonic we all know and love, but it is slightly better than episode 1. This game is really only for bored gamers waiting for something interesting to happen and for crazy Sonic fans who collect every Sonic game known in exsistance both good and bad.4.7/10But hey, at least it's better than Sonic Unleashed!Before I go, there is one more problem with game. If you get all of the Chaos Emeralds and beat the game, you don't get some cool "true ending" cutscene, or even a picture of Super Sonic, dissapointing I know.

												Episode 2 is a marked improvement over Episode 1, but still doesn't quite match the legacy it's trying to emulate. The difficulty is uneven, the boss fights are some of the most tedious in the Sonic franchise, and the music is repetitive to the point of being annoying. Co-op is the coolest part, but it doesn't save the game from being aggressively mediocre at best.Level design lacks the clear purposeful simplicity of old Sonic games. It plays well enough, I suppose, but lacks the imaginative spark of creativity the series was once known for, instead coming off as hackneyed "What if we took one old level and mashed it up with this other one?" Originality is not this game's strongest suit.Difficulty is extremely unbalanced. You can breeze through most of the game on autopilot, but every now and then you'll hit a speed bump that will have you stuck for a frustratingly long amount of time. It makes the game feel uneven and sloppy.Most of those speed bumps will probably be the game's boss encounters, which feature excessive, flashy animation sequences that will keep you waiting. Every time you fight one of the game's bosses, you'll have to sit through a cutscene that shows them "getting ready" to fight. Some of these cutscenes can last a full minute, and you have to re-watch them every time you die. Death comes often in these boss fights, which can last upwards of five minutes (a really long time for a boss!) and offer no checkpoints. Dying on the last hit only to have to sit through a minute-long cutscene for the third time is the pits.Even music, typically a high point for most Sonic games (even the really bad ones!) falls extremely flat. It's generic retro video game music, but does not evoke the old Sonic games in the slightest. It's too tinny, too repetitive, too annoying. Oil Desert Act 2 in particular will grate on your nerves, with a meowing synth instrument that doesn't sound like anything on earth. Classic Sonic games were trying to evoke real instruments on limited hardware, but this just sounds like hissing, scratchy square wave nonsense. Chiptunes for the sake of having chiptunes.If there was one part of this game that felt genuinely inspired, it would be the game's two-player online co-op mode. This ends up being a legitimate improvement over co-op modes in past Sonic games, given each player gets their own separate view instead of having to share the screen. The game's flying stage, similar to Sonic 2's Sky Chase Zone, ends up being particularly harrowing in this mode. Here, Player 2 flies the plane, and is burdened with the task of getting Player 1 in to position -- a truly cooperative experience.The game is almost worth it for the co-op alone. Almost... but not quite.

												As some others have said, Episode II is a big improvement over episode I, and I haven't played completely through both games, though I do find them enjoyable. The price is way too high, so just get the Hits collection to pick them up so you have something else to play when you're really, REALLY bored. In good conscience, I can't recommend either Sonic 4 episodes - am I the only one that can notice how SLOW these games are? Is it just me? The trailers looked like the games moved much faster, but then when I play them, much, much slower. It used to be that you could finish a level in about 1-2 minutes or so, it feels as if they artificially slowed down the game so that you'll take longer to complete it and they can say it's longer. If I'm wrong, I'd be happy to be corrected. As a long time Sega fan bordering on "fanboy" status (but not quite as manic and irritating) I have to wonder what Sonic Team was thinking. The Good Points: I think the graphics are gorgeous. New high-stylized Sonic does look a little odd in a 2-D platformer, but the levels look nice and the artwork is on point. The combine gimmicks are fun to an extent which makes for some cute "aw" moments. In other words, the game is great to look at. It doesn't lose points there. As has been said many times before I got anywhere near it, the physics are VERY improved over the first Sonic 4 game. Boss battles are cool looking and great. The Bad Points: Gimmicks are gimmicks are gimmicks, they DO get tired after a little while. This isn't my biggest gripe with the game, however, which is that the game just feels way slower than any previous Sonic title. If they slowed this down in an attempt to get new people interested in the games, they alienated their original fanbase that enjoyed the games for their fast-paced fluidness. These games aren't fluid, they're clunky and slow. Improved physics over the first installment or not, they're simply too slow-paced to get a good rhythm and pace going throughout the games. The music is really, really bad. Mute the music and put on some of your own tunes, just don't play anything too fast because the game's pacing is a mix between the average tempos of Pink Floyd and Enya. How are you gonna slow down Sonic? Some parts will make you feel like you're playing the 2012 version of Atari 2600 E.T.On one final note, I have to say that someone at Sega REALLY likes sparkles. They will absolutely put a sparkle type effect on anything they can just to use that one sound effect that they made a few years ago over, and over, and over, and over again. There's nothing entirely wrong with this sound effect, it just gets kind of boring after awhile.Decent effort, but I don't feel this does anything to improve the controversial and arguable standards of the franchise considering the previous installments (and I DO think that Sonic Generations was a lot of fun and is a lot more fun than these, because they didn't slow Sonic down.) 5/10 - Sonic disaster, not sonic speed and playability. Again, it's not all bad, get it in the Hits collection, but don't spend the money on the game by itself.

												Despite not completely following the formula that was established in Sonic 1, 2 & 3(and Knuckles) It's still a very functional game that perhaps is more catered to a slightly more modern audience, since the classic games play in a more 1990s sort of fashion. You can feel the difference with a lighter Sonic and feels a bit more fluid than in previous 2D games. So for long time Sonic fans you may still be thrown off by the unfaithful physics that don't reflect the old-school days of 2D Sonic, but they are a step up from what Episode I had to offer because of some added tweaks to the game engine and, and some subtle changes to Sonic in this game too, such as how he no longer uncurls out of a Spin when jumping of a slope. And since Episode II is a seperate game that you have to pay for individually (and with Sonic 3 and Sonic & Knuckles it's easy to buy the two games together) Sonic 4 Episode II doesn't offer too much a sequel since it doesn't really expand but rather just pay a homage to Classic Sonic, so if you we're hoping to see more than what Sonic 3 & Knuckles offered, then even with both episodes combined, you won't really get that here. However it's still a fun game that any fan of Sonic should give a go, and can even appeal to people who aren't necessarily fans of Sonic. It's not amazing, but a good game nontheless.

												Don’t be put off by the game’s lack of commercial success. First it should be said the both parts of Sonic 4, Episode 1 (4.1) and Episode 2 (4.2) seem to have an identity crisis. They are officially sequels but in reality they are something of an updated remake, 4.1 and 4.2 borrow and reference Sonic 1, 2, 3&K and CD heavily; 4.1s bosses are all remakes of the originals, a fault 4.2 even references with the first boss originally appearing to mimic the Aquatic Ruins’ Boss before transforming into something new. However even it borrows the later levels and boss fights. The level design 4.2 is also much better than 4.1’s. As 4.2 has original zones; Sylvanian Castle, Winter Park Zone and the Oil Desert (whose features resemble 3&K’s Sandopolis much more than Sonic 2’s Oil Ocean which it would appear to be a copy of at first glance). After this 4.2 does fall into copying the final zone which is just an amalgamation of Wing Fortress, Sky Chase and the Flying Battery zones, taking features from each but making them worse (in the Sky Chase knock off for example Tail’s Plane can disappear leaving the player plummeting to earth).There are problems with both games; they both insist on the use of Sonic’s homing attack to access ledges which I find it unnecessary for a side-scroller. Again Physics does not seem to apply in Sonic the Hedgehog’s universe, he can walk up walls when travelling at fairly low speeds (although not as badly as he could in 06), while the homing attack creates momentum from nothing.Even the traditional saving grace of the Sonic game, the soundtrack, is poor which is disappointing. In addition, the game also has a very short life span, 4.1 failed to keep me attached for more than 5 hours, and while 4.2 actually saw me to completion, it only has at most 5-12 hours of gameplay depending on how quickly you can master it and I doubt either has much in the way of replay value unlike the games they are based upon.This said however, for once Sonic actually controls well (which he never does in 3D Games). 4.2 itself still contains a number of very good features. The inclusion of team mechanics was a great idea as it makes Tails a valued partner to Sonic, his abilities have made him an essential part as he can get Sonic through traps and defeat opponents. 4.2 also did well with the special stages, which like 4.1s are copies of the original games (this time the tunnel runs of Sonic 2,) unlike 4.1 however, 4.2 improves the originals. Tails is no longer a dead weight, he doesn't drop rings when hit and a new power up (a chaotix ring type feature) can give new interesting challenges, it is just a pity they weren’t used more often.Therefore although neither are great like the games they were trying to emulate, they are ok and I generally do not see why they have been so badly received as they’re worthy successors to the original Sonic. 4.1 may be distinctly average but 4.2 is a big improvement upon it. The current price tags are not value for money but if you pick them up in the Steam sale (as I did) 4.2 is certainly worth a fiver. 4.1 should only be purchased if you want the bonus Metal Sonic Mode which works when you own both parts.Sonic 4 Episode 1 4/10Sonic 4 Episode 2 7/10

												Sonic The Hedgehog 4 - Episode 2 is the second episode of Sonic 4 project, which is 2D Platformer with multiplayer, came out in 2012, two years after the first one. It ended up being the last episode in the project, with no news on Episode 3 ever since. Outside of "it's pretty much cancelled". No big differences between mobile and other versions this time around.Owners of Episode 1 on Steam will also get Episode Metal bonus.No complaints on technical side this time around, it supports all the needed resolutions.Being an episode, you may think it's very short. Well, it's decend old platformer lenght. You are given 4 zones with 3 acts each, plus boss act. Add to that final level and special stages. Each act is adds long enough overall for it to be considered to be about as long as, say, Sonic 1. So don't knock this title off for being "not full game".This time around Sonic doesn't travel by himself. The ever cute Tails the fox joins him and becomes part of the team. And he isn't just wasting space either, as the game introduces ability to call Tails to help you. He can lift you up in air, let you travel underwater or you can do a combined spin-dash. Said spin-dash breaks through special walls, destroyes everything and simply goes really fast. Yes, I said a cliche thing. You can't turn around in this mode and it will stop by itself after colliding with a wall three times. In all honesty, I don't like this move. It either will be abusive, making some sections go too easy, or will give you cheap deaths of falling into pits you couldn't possibly see before too late. Try not too use it too much.Oh, and takling of pits. Game for once actually puts signs over bottomless pits, so you know if it will kill you or just a way to lower path. The fact that you can call Tails to save you by lifting into air with push of a single button helps you to get out of this sticky situation where you are already falling into one. Quite clever thing, if you ask me.Now, it's not the first time you have Tails as sidekick. When he was first introduced in Sonic 2, he was giving game much of good. Second player could exploit that Tails always respawns to make bosses too easy, while AI would ruin special stages for you. He would later learn to fly in Sonic 3, also being able to lift Sonic along, but you had to grab Second Player's controller to do that and thus was only used to find rare bonuses. Sonic 2 bad sides of Tails were still there.Then in Sonic Advance 3, with it's sidekick system, you could take Tails along with you and could easily use his ability as single-player to help you. But because you could take any different sidekick with very different abilities, game was still using them for optional things, like finding bonus items or just helping usual process.In Sonic 4 Episode 2 though he is always your sidekick. Thus the game actively uses it and even throws challenges that requrie Tails help. For example, at the end of one of the acts in the Oil Desert you have to use Tails to hover slowly, while avoiding enemies and being pushed around by wind. By the way, flight isn't timed, instead you can "lift yourself up sllightly" only limited times.You can't abuse Tails for bosses either, as when it comes to multiplayer, from what I know, the lives are limited for Tails. Or maybe they are shared.In all honesty, I didn't try multiplayer out. But I think it should be real nice. Sonic can call Tails to his location, so Tails player will not feel left out that camera only follows Sonic. And yes, it has all the needed options and system to play over Internet. Maybe even too much, it's just 2-player coop of short platform game after all.I didn't find anybody active online there. So you should just use it to play with friend, not going to find strangers. Then again, playing with friend is the way it should be done anyway.Game also fixes some of the main complaints and just improves. Levels still have pacing, platforming and few paths. Actually, each level has one red ring hidden in it that you can collect. In other Sonic games it usually unlocks something. Here it doesn't do anything aside from giving achievement and just being something to explore levels for. They say that it had some use for upcoming Episode 3, but as it's not being developed, well, yea. Each act also tries to get something unique going for it, but there is still ntohing like darkness and carts.Physics are good. They are still not on par with older Genesis titles, so it's not a game about rolling down the slopes. But they about as good as other modern 2D Sonic games, so there should be no complaints. Still got platforming going for it after all.And I also should mention that this time around game doesn't feel like it tries to restrict itself. It finally feels like continuation to classic trilogy. Perhaps this one should have been the real Episode One, really. Bosses are epic, Metal Sonic makes awesome return too. This game actually does the best justice to this villian. Final boss is huge, unique and isn't easy-easy. You will even get to take down flying fortress again. And yes, there is stage where you fly on top of Tornado plane and it's more complicated than original in Sonic 2. Other zones are also unique and don't feel as much of deja vu like in Episode 1.Shame though that some boss acts are too generous with throwing rings at you non-stop. Ah well, at least battles themselves felt enjoyable.Graphics are great. It's all modern 3D now, using polygons for backgroudn details as well, not using that simplistic shading effect of Episode 1 either. While not requiring much of computer, it strikes some beautiful sceneries.Same can be said of music. In Episode 1 it felt like bad experiement at some times. In Episode Two majority of it is great. It seemed to find it's own identify and provides some unique feel that you will not find in original trilogy, providing tensity too. Oil Desert Act 2 comes to mind, which has a bit of that old-school lo-fi feel, while also giving you a feeling of being in hot oily desert. Burning. Normal boss music is still too repetitive.You can still collect 7 emeralds in special stages, which are similiar to Special Stages in Sonic 2, where you run through a tube and collect rings. No twists this time, just additional small features. That, and it's still better than Sonic 2 ones because you can actually see things before they hit you. Some of them are hard, so you will either learn to abuse "retry" button in menu or will have to do it in multiplayer.Episode Metal allows you to go through the Episode 1 levels as Metal Sonic. No sidekick. Metal even has same shading to him there as characters in the first Episode. You will just go through one act of each of the four zones. And layout of that act is changed heavily. Could say that it's unique ones. But using elements from what you already seen before. At least they aren't too easy.So, Sonic 4 Episode 2 is a pretty good platformer and 2D Sonic game. Better than Episode 1 for sure and actually feels more like proper Sonic 4. You should have fun with it. The only shame is that ending may feel cliffhangery for some.

While the first two acts you could probably breeze through, the next two, Oil Desert and Sky Fortress, just surge in difficulty where the first two had it in small bursts. The worst part, however, is the bosses. Again, the first two bosses are not all that difficult if you have some knowledge of the mechanics of the game. The third boss in Oil Desert, however, is mostly boring climbing and occasionally waiting for Eggman to reveal his weak spot. However, the point where I stopped playing, and I am pretty sure that I cannot give this game anything other than a 'not recommended' review after having game over'd from it twice, is Sky Fortress's boss.To put it shortly, Sky Fortress has you fighting Metal Sonic in the blue carrier from before. However, his strategy is far different from Sky Fortress Act 1. For the first portion of the fight, he will move to either the top or the bottom of the screen and fire screen-filling lasers at you.  You have to hit Metal Sonic in the cockpit, which, provided you don't completely outrun the carrier yourself, is somewhat easy. The next phase is also fairly self-explanatory: Metal Sonic will move to the right side of the screen and fire bird bots and lasers along the screen, simply avoid him and hit Metal Sonic. The last part, however, is down-right impossible at first glance. The screen fills up with missiles (apparently supposed to be in the background), and much larger missiles fly towards you, albeit rotating as they come to you. What it doesn't tell you, however, is that the one move designed to destroy stuff in the way, the team-up command, doesn't break through the missiles, but it is instead to hit Metal Sonic who is way out in front. If you can't keep up with the screen, you are thrown back to the beginning of the battle. Mind, this battle is fairly long, and, again, they don't tell you ANYTHING during the fight, except on what half of the screen the missiles take up. If you're lucky you can get multiple hits on MS in the earlier portions to speed up everything, but what's the point if you die in one hit at the end of the battle unless you have the reflexes of some kind of god or something?There's a reason the classic games' bosses were simple, but not so simple that a monkey could simply wail on a genesis controller and win. Well... there's a reason THREE of the four classic games didn't do that. Sonic 2's bosses were kind of REALLY easy at times. So, for a game supposed to be a modern game built as a sequel to the classic quadrilogy, this fails pretty cohesively as a sequel, even if Sonic 4 Episode 1 apparently failed that much harder.

												This game is a bit of a mixed bag.  Sega fixed the problems from episode 1 with the way Sonic moves and tried some new ideas, but a number of them failed miserably.The good things first:  The graphics are definitely improved and they got rid of the ugly fake 16 bit look from Sonic.  Sonic moves better and doesn't feel so sluggish.  Sega tried a lot of new ideas and came up with some pretty unique levels which are a pretty nice change from previous games.Now the bad:  A lot of that new unique stuff is terrible, flow breaking, and annoying.  Some new enemies seem to be designed to always hit you if you're going fast like Sonic should.  Some parts of the new level designs are rather annoying, especially the way they ham-fisted the Tails combo abilities in.  In order to reach the fast path in a lot of levels you seem to be required to use Tails' flying ability to reach places you can't even see.  There's also a combo rolling attack which is required to break down some barriers.  The game prompts you every time you're required to use them to continue in the level, and they mainly serve as an annoyance.  And the other problem with the levels...they actually added a scrolling level in the game.  That's right, in a game where the whole point is to be as fast as possible, they added a slow scroller (and Sonic becomes extremely sluggish on this level as well).Now the biggest problem with the game: the bosses.  Without exception, the bosses are all extremely annoying and tedious fights.  Bosses are a lot more complicated than previous games, take many more hits to kill, and of course require Tails combo abilities at certain not-so-obvious spots.  They also tend to have very long start and transition sequences that you have to wait through every time if you fail.  One of the bosses even uses the scrolling level set up to make it as annoying as humanly possible to fight him.I got to the final boss, and fighting him is so annoying that I can't even be bothered to finish the game.  Do yourself a favor and just get Episode 1 and Generations.  This one isn't worth it.
